content.location: On the east end of the crag.  Start on the face below the obvious snaggletooth.  Follow the flakes up and left.  Good pro along the way.  Girth hitch the "eye socket".  A micro cam or small stopper will protect the crux nicely.  Lie back the flakes above.  Stay on the left face.  Sling flakes for pro. Then move up a right to the exit move at the top of a ragged left-facing corner.  Drop in a big hex and finish.

climbs.name: Ledge Monkey
climbs.fa: Ellie Borton and Jim Borton, April 29, 2020

content.description: Climb the face to the left of the left facing corner.  Aim for the flake directly overhead.  Find a couple of good placements for small cams, tricams, or nuts.  Pull up to the ledge and get a good left arm bar in the large crack just over the lip.  Plug in a bomber cam.  Now lie back (sort of) and swing up and to your right.  Channel your inner primate and monkey onto the ledge. Lie back the flake above you.  Find a couple of cam placements behind the flake.  Move right onto the face and finish on edges.
content.location: Find the flakes and the overhanging bulge to the left of the left facing corner, about 30 feet to the left of the big chimney.

climbs.name: Garlic and Onions
climbs.fa: Ellie Borton and Jim Borton, April 29, 2020

content.description: Easy slab climbing with good protection.  Crux is near the bottom as you climb the small left-facing slab and gain the ledge above.  "Garlic and Onions" because that's what The Gunpowder smells like in spring.
content.location: Far right of the main face.  Route begins in the crack in the small left-facing slab.  Gain the ledge above.  This is the crux and maybe easier than 5.4, if you are really tall.  Place solid gear at the back of the ledge.  Move up and right.  Place more gear in right-facing flakes.  Use care because some of the rock is friable.  Move up and slightly left over easy slab climbing with big holds.

climbs.name: Dirty Chimney Escape
climbs.fa: April 25, 2021.  Alex Hill and Jim Borton.

content.description: Get dirty in the chimney.  Escape right onto the nose. Beware of moss.
content.location: Obvious chimney in the middle of the crag.

content.description: Crux at the top.  An airy step from the right wall to the left.  The name of this climb comes from Mark Kochte's 2002 Climb Maryland! guidebook.
content.location: Find the obvious chimney to the left of the nose.

content.description: Nearby adventure climbing. Top rope and trad in a beautiful setting.  Great views overlooking a bend in the Gunpowder.  A cascade. A pair of bald eagles.  This crag faces south and is often sunny and warm in the winter.  Some friable rock, so pay attention. Helmets are a good idea. However, most of the rock is more solid than it looks.
